conclusion: To determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground, we need to consider the effects of air resistance and the inelastic collision.
The image shows two cars with a warning sign labeled 'BRAKE'.
The basketball is dropped from rest at height H.
The gravitational force acting on the basketball is mg.
Net force during descent: mg - λmg = mg(1 - λ).
Acceleration during descent: a_d = g(1 - λ).
Using kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as with u = 0, v_d^2 = 2a_dH = 2g(1 - λ)H.
Net force during ascent: mg + λmg = mg(1 + λ).
Acceleration during ascent: a_u = g(1 + λ).
Using kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as with final velocity v = 0 at height h, 0 = v_u^2 - 2a_uh = v_u^2 - 2g(1 + λ)h.
Ratio of post-collision to pre-collision velocity: (v_u/v_d) = √((1 + λ)h/(1 - λ)H).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is √((1 + λ)h/(1 - λ)H).
